title: Astros' Yordan Álvarez couldn't have picked a better time to deliver first postseason homer
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Game 5 was setting up to be a series defining game and then the Nationals received devastating news from their ace pitcher and the Astros capitalized. As Trysta Krick details, Washington is brink while the Astros are one game away from a classic comeback. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – After having one of the greatest rookie seasons in major league baseball history, Yordan Álvarez of the Houston Astros had gone cold in the postseason.

He struggled through 1-for-22 performance in the American League Championship Series, and as the World Series came to Washington, he had been relegated to pinch-hitting duties.

But a return to the Astros starting lineup in Game 5 Sunday night was just what Alvarez needed to get back on track. Only, he wasn’t the first one to know.

“All my teammates were saying today is your day. Today is your day,” Álvarez said after going 3-for-3 with a home run in the Astros’ 7-1 victory.

Jose Alvarez celebrates his second-inning homer with teammate Jose Altuve. (Photo: Patrick Smith, Getty Images)

Shortstop Carlos Correa and backup infielder Aledmys Diaz were the most vocal ones, giving the rookie encouragement as he spent past several days working on making the necessary adjustments to get out of his October slump.

“I just told him that what great players do when they struggle is try to figure out a way to contribute to the game,” Correa said. “He went to the cage. He spent time in the cage. He put in his work. And he told me he was feeling great.”

Despite not getting a call to the majors until early June, Álvarez still hit 27 home runs, collected 78 RBI and put up a .313/.412/.655 slash line. Those numbers have made him the prohibitive favorite for AL Rookie of the Year honors.

And with good reason. Among players with at least 350 plate appearances, no rookie has ever had a higher slugging percentage. No rookie has ever posted a higher OPS (1.067). Even adjusting for era, ballpark factors and offensive environments, only Jose Abreu in 2014 has been able to equal Alvarez’s 173 OPS+.

WHAT IF:Nationals have to live with iffy calls in Game 5

GAME 5: Nationals on the ropes after third straight loss

WORLD SERIES: Fans were ready for President Trump's visit

With such a stellar resume, Álvarez, 22, hadn’t really experienced failure the way he did in the ALCS against the New York Yankees. Then with the World Series moving to the National League park, the Astros’ everyday DH during the regular season found himself on the bench for Games 3 and 4.

“Things didn’t go as well as he wanted to, but he had a great season,” said first baseman Yuli Gurriel. “So I always give him the advice to keep your spirits up, keep working. And we saw what happened tonight.”

Astros manager A.J. Hinch had said earlier in the series he wanted to get Álvarezinto a game in the outfield, even though he only made 10 appearances there during the regular season. With Gerrit Cole – who led the majors with 326 strikeouts this season – on the mound, Game 5 was the perfect opportunity.

“You want to talk about feeling like you did the right thing is just put Yordan in the game and have him have three incredible at-bats,” Hinch said. “He’s done this the whole year, but this postseason as he’s tried to find his way it was nice to see him stay within himself.”

He even made a nice catch in the field on Trea Turner’s sizzling line drive in the third inning.

But perhaps the biggest reason the Astros are so optimistic heading back home to Houston with a chance to wrap up their second World Series title in three years isn’t that they’ll have their co-ace Justin Verlander on the mound in Game 6. It’s that they’ll have their rookie slugger – now clearly back in the groove – back in the lineup for good.

“It’s huge to see him swing the bat like that because now we go back home and then he’s our DH at 22 years old for a reason,” Correa said. “He’s young and he’s powerful and he’s a great hitter. So we believe in him and we know he’s going to keep doing it.”
description: Álvarez had 27 home runs in 87 regular-season games, but hadn't gone long in the postseason – until Game 5.
